## SQL: Statement Fundamentals


### COUNT

The COUNT function returns the number of input rows that match a specific condition of a query.

**Syntax**:

```{sql, eval = FALSE}
-- COUNT
SELECT COUNT(*)/ COUNT(column)/ COUNT(DISTINCT column)
FROM table;
```

**Example**: Number of transactions in the payment table

```{sql, eval = FALSE}
-- Count the number of transactions in the payment table
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM payment;
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(RPostgreSQL)
connPostgres = dbConnect(
  dbDriver("PostgreSQL"), dbname="dvdrental", 
  host="localhost", port=5432, 
  user="postgres", password="asshole"
)
DBI::dbGetQuery(connPostgres,
"
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM payment
")
```

**Example**: Number of distinct transactions in the payment table

```{sql, eval = FALSE}
-- Count the number of transactions in the payment table
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT(amount))
FROM payment;
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(RPostgreSQL)
connPostgres = dbConnect(
  dbDriver("PostgreSQL"), dbname="dvdrental", 
  host="localhost", port=5432, 
  user="postgres", password="asshole"
)
DBI::dbGetQuery(connPostgres,
"
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT(amount))
FROM payment
")
```
